title: Justin Trudeau asked by children why he painted his face brown
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Justin Trudeau has been quizzed by children over his decision to paint his face brown.

The Canadian Prime Minister, 47, appeared on a Facebook Watch show called ‘New Mom, Who Dis?’, hosted by TV personality Jesse Cruickshank.

During the show, which aired online today, Trudeau was faced with five young children who were allowed to ask him any questions they wanted.

At first he was questioned over whether he lives in a mansion, before two girls stood up and asked: ‘Why did you paint your face brown?’

Trudeau looked slightly surprised at the question, immediately responding: ‘Ooh. It was something I shouldn’t have done because it hurt people.

Justin Trudeau appeared on Facebook Watch series ‘New Mom, Who Dis?’ (Picture: New Mom, Who Dis?)

He apologised for his actions to the girls (Picture: New Mom, Who Dis?)

‘It’s not something that you should do and that is something that I learned. I didn’t know it back then and I know it now, and I’m sorry that I hurt people.’

The girls then persisted with their questioning, asking again: ‘But did you paint your nose and your hands brown?’

Nodding, Trudeau replied: ‘Mmm-hmm. Yeah. And it was the wrong thing to do.’

Trudeau has recently come under fire after evidence of three separate instances in which he had dressed in brownface came to light.

One image showed the prime minister wearing dark make up to a party at a private school he had been teaching at in 2001.

A picture of him dressed in brownface at a school function emerged (Picture: AP)

The video was filmed during the early 1990s (Picture: Global News)

Printed in the school yearbook, it was taken at an Arabian Nights-themed event, when Trudeau was 29.

Another image reveals Trudeau wearing brown makeup to sing Jamaican folk song Day O while in a high school talent show.

A third video, shot in the early 1990s, shows him making faces while covered in dark make up, wearing a T-shirt and ripped jeans.

In his apology for images, Trudeau said: ‘Darkening your face, regardless of the context or circumstances, is always unacceptable because of the racist history of blackface.

‘I should have understood that then and I never should have done it.’
